Improve My Relationship with My Child.tips.intro: 6ï¸âƒ£ Here are 6 tips for how you can help Your Child learn how to cope with their emotions: LEARN, NOTICE, OPEN, TALK, SHARE and CARE
Improve My Relationship with My Child.tips.message.1.text:
1ï¸âƒ£ LEARN

ğŸ’¡ Learn about different emotions. There are 6 basic emotions that each send us a very specific message:  

ğŸ˜ƒHappy: Keep doing things that make you feel good.  

ğŸ˜”Sad: Something important in your life needs attention.

ğŸ”´Angry: Stand up for ourselves and set limits.

ğŸ˜£Disgusted: Move away from what we don't like.

ğŸ‘€Surprised: Stop and pay attention for a moment.

ğŸš©Afraid: Run away from danger.

ğŸ¨ As children get older, they learn to identify lots of other emotions, like feeling excited, frustrated, proud, lonely, peaceful, guilty, or confused.
Improve My Relationship with My Child.tips.message.2.text:
2ï¸âƒ£ NOTICE

ğŸ‘€ Begin observing these 6 emotions in yourself and in Your Child.
ğŸ˜ƒğŸ˜’ğŸ˜”ğŸ˜£Notice how each emotion feels in your body.  
 
ğŸ˜ƒ You can also notice positive emotions such as a sense of peace, happiness, or calmness.
ğŸ’™ Noticing can also help children appreciate a beautiful moment or feeling of love!
Improve My Relationship with My Child.tips.message.3.text:
3ï¸âƒ£ OPEN

Be open, notice ğŸ‘€, and listen ğŸ‘‚ to Your Child when they share how they are feeling. 
ğŸ’› Accept how you and Your Child feel. Remember, your body and their body are sending messages about what you both are feeling, and those messages are important.
Improve My Relationship with My Child.tips.message.4.text:
4ï¸âƒ£ TALK

ğŸ˜’ It is normal to struggle to talk about and express emotions and feelings. 

ğŸ“ Remember, it is also normal to experience feelings in different ways.

â­ When Your Child is feeling an emotion, describe what you are observing in a calm way. For example, 

â€œI notice youâ€™re stomping your feet, talking loudly, and your face looks a bit upset. Are you feeling angry because you didnâ€™t get to play outside?â€

You can also help Your Child learn different emotions by using facial expressions and physical movements. Make it into a game.
Improve My Relationship with My Child.tips.message.5.text:
5ï¸âƒ£ SHARE

ğŸ˜ƒ Share your own feelings with Your Child. For example, â€œI would feel the same way if I couldnâ€™t go out when I wanted to.â€ 

 ğŸˆThis sets a good example and shows Your Child that it's okay to share their own feelings.
Improve My Relationship with My Child.tips.message.6.text:
6ï¸âƒ£ CARE

Improve My Relationship with My Child.introduction.msg_list: This lesson is about how we can stay calm and manage our anger when dealing with stressful moments with our children. ğŸ’š
Improve My Relationship with My Child.importance.msg_list:
As you began noticing feelings, you would have noticed feelings of anger, frustration or sadness. 

ğŸŒ· We love our children, but stress from caregiving and other events can make us feel angry. This is a normal part of life! 

ğŸ’¡ It is important for us to try to stay calm in order to help manage our anger so we do not hurt others.

Improve My Relationship with My Child.tips.intro: There are 4ï¸âƒ£steps to keeping calm in stressful situations: BE CALM, QUICK, CLEAR, and POSITIVE.
Improve My Relationship with My Child.tips.message.1.text:
1ï¸âƒ£ *BE CALM*

âœ… Be aware of your own feelings.

âœ… Take a pause or a few breaths before asking Your Child to do something else.

âœ… Speak with Your Child in a calm voice.

âœ… Remember your goal: Make Your Child feel loved and connected to you.
Improve My Relationship with My Child.tips.message.2.text:
2ï¸âƒ£ *BE QUICK*

â° There are other things you can do to help manage unwanted behaviour before it becomes stressful. 

âœ¨ Praise something positive that Your Child did today. 

âœ¨ Understand their feelings. For example, it may feel boring to pick up toys after having fun or ending a big task. 

âœ¨ When you see Your Child is about to start an unwanted behaviour, distract them by asking them to do something else, before the unwanted behaviour begins or gets worse. 

âœ¨Invite Your Child in a chore you are doing. You can ask Your Child to think of a fun and quick way of doing the chores differently. 

ğŸ’¡ Preventing unwanted behaviour is much easier than disciplining them after they have done something wrong!
Improve My Relationship with My Child.tips.message.3.text:
3ï¸âƒ£ *BE CLEAR*

âœ… Rather than saying what you DONâ€™T want, tell Your Child what you DO want them to do.

For example, say:

âœ¨ â€œPlease speak more softly.â€ 
(instead of â€œstop shoutingâ€)

âœ¨ â€œRemember to walk inside the house.â€
(instead of â€œstop runningâ€)

This way, it is easier for them to follow! â­
Improve My Relationship with My Child.tips.message.4.text:
4ï¸âƒ£ *BE POSITIVE*

âœ… Praise Your Child when they behave well!

âœ… Invite Your Child to a positive activity when you see they are about to start an unwanted behaviour. 

âœ… It will also help them know what you expect from them!

Keep My Child Safe & Healthy.comic.intro: {F1_FATHER} wants to help his young children learn about safe and unsafe touch. Letâ€™s see how he has the conversation with his young son, {F1_SON_5}.
Keep My Child Safe & Healthy.comic.text.1:
{F1_FATHER}: Did you enjoy the story, {F1_SON_5}?

{F1_SON_5}: Yes, {F1_FATHER}! It was fun!
Keep My Child Safe & Healthy.comic.text.2:
{F1_FATHER}:  Now, there are some important things I want to talk to you about. It's about keeping your body safe and healthy.

{F1_SON_5}: What do you mean, {F1_FATHER}?
Keep My Child Safe & Healthy.comic.text.3:
{F1_FATHER}: First, we all have private parts on our bodies. These are the parts that are covered by our underwear.

{F1_SON_5}: Like this? 

{F1_FATHER}: Exactly. It's important to remember that these parts are private, and no one should touch them except to keep you clean and healthy.
Keep My Child Safe & Healthy.comic.text.4:
{F1_FATHER}: Your body belongs to you, and you have the right to say 'no' if someone wants to touch you in a way that feels uncomfortable or wrong.

{F1_SON_5}: Okay, {F1_FATHER}.
Keep My Child Safe & Healthy.comic.text.5:
{F1_FATHER}: And if anything ever happens that makes you feel scared or uneasy, remember you can always come and tell me or {F1_MOTHER}. We're here to protect you and keep you safe.

{F1_SON_5}: I will tell you and {F1_MOTHER}, {F1_FATHER}.

{F1_FATHER}: We love you, {F1_SON_5}. Now, let's give each other a big hug!
Keep My Child Safe & Healthy.tips.intro: 4ï¸âƒ£ Here are four tips to help you teach Your Child about safe and unsafe touch and what to do if they feel unsafe when someone touches them. ğŸ’›
Keep My Child Safe & Healthy.tips.message.1.text:
1ï¸âƒ£ LEARN ABOUT PRIVATE PARTS

âœ… The parts of their body that go under their underwear or a swimsuit are private parts. 
âŒ It is not OK for other people to touch or to ask to look at them, or ask them to look at or touch theirs.
Keep My Child Safe & Healthy.tips.message.2.text:
2ï¸âƒ£ â€œNOâ€ IS OK!

âŒ Tell Your Child that they are always allowed to say no to someone touching them. This is true even for things like hugs!
ğŸ‘‘ This teaches Your Child that they are always in control of who they allow to touch them so they can make safe choices throughout their lives, in any situation.
ğŸš© Practise saying â€œNo, please donâ€™t do thatâ€ and â€œNo! Stop!â€ with Your Child, so they know how to do it if they need to.
Keep My Child Safe & Healthy.tips.message.3.text:
3ï¸âƒ£ GET AWAY

ğŸ’¡ Always teach Your Child how to get away from any situation where they feel uncomfortable. 
ğŸš© Offenders are usually known to the child and/or caregivers and initially engage in physical activities like wrestling or touching. This is to get the child comfortable with touch.
â— When playing physical games like wrestling with your child, practice saying "no" and respecting their boundaries. If your child says "no", stop the game immediately.
ğŸŒ· This empowers them to say â€œNO!â€ to unsafe situations outside the home as well.  It will not be as easy for the child to get away from such situations, but teaching them how to leave when they feel uncomfortable will help.
Keep My Child Safe & Healthy.tips.message.4.text:
4ï¸âƒ£ TELL AN ADULT

ğŸ”´ Tell Your Child that if they feel worried, uncomfortable, or unsafe about anyone touching them, they should tell you or an adult they trust. Always believe your child when they tell you about someone touching them in an unsafe way.
ğŸ‘‚ If Your Child tells you about something that has happened, listen openly and tell them they were right to tell you. Then, take steps to keep them safe, including not ever leaving them alone with anyone that makes them feel unsafe.

Understand Child Development.introduction.msg_list: This lesson is about taking care of yourself. ğŸŒ±
Understand Child Development.tips.intro: Here is a simple stretching and movement activity that may help you with stress:
Understand Child Development.tips.message.1.text:
Stand up and stretch your arms up to the sky. 
...
Push away any clouds and let the sun shine down on you. 
...
Stretch to both sides. 
...
Stretch to the front and to the back.
Understand Child Development.tips.message.2.text:
Let your hands hang by your side. 
...
Squeeze your shoulders tightly up to your ears as you breathe in, scrunch your eyes, and hold your breath. 
...
Release your shoulders as you relax your body.
Understand Child Development.tips.message.3.text:
Relax your arms and let them swing to the front and back. Take four deep breaths while you do this. This is good for your lower back.
...
Relax your arms, let them swing sideways, and turn your upper body. Your arms should gently hit your back as you twist from side to side.
Understand Child Development.tips.message.4.text: Place one foot in front of the other and make small circles from the ankles. Remember to turn to both sides. Do each foot with four circles in each direction.
Understand Child Development.tips.message.5.text: Now, shake your whole body as fast as you can. Shake it up high! Shake it down low! Shake it all around!
Understand Child Development.tips.message.6.text:
Close your eyes and raise your arms slowly above your head as you breathe in. Lower your arms slowly to your side as you breathe out. 
...
Raise and lower your arms, breathing in and out 4 more times.
Understand Child Development.tips.message.7.text:
Take a moment to reflect on your experience. 
...
Remember that you can do this activity at any time whenever you feel like you need to release stress and energise your mind and body.

Supporting Positive Child Behaviour.introduction.msg_list: This skill is about what to do when children are seeking attention with demanding and negative behaviours. ğŸš©

Supporting Positive Child Behaviour.quiz.content.1.question: True or False: You should give your child what they want when they are whining about something or having a tantrum.
Supporting Positive Child Behaviour.quiz.content.1.feedback_correct:
â­ Thatâ€™s correct! 

Giving your child attention when they are whining or having a tantrum will only make it worse.

Your child will learn that they get rewarded with attention (even negative attention) when they behave that way.

Instead, try to give your child plenty of positive attention when they behave positively (like accepting when you say they cannot have something they want).
Supporting Positive Child Behaviour.quiz.content.1.feedback_incorrect:
âŒ Thatâ€™s incorrect. 

Giving your child attention when they are whining or having a tantrum will only make it worse.

âŒ Thatâ€™s incorrect.

Supporting Positive Child Behaviour.tips.intro: 5ï¸âƒ£ There are five steps to reduce negative, attention-seeking and demanding behaviour, such as whining or throwing tantrums.
Supporting Positive Child Behaviour.tips.message.1.text:
1ï¸âƒ£ REDIRECT

ğŸ¨ Be calm, quick, clear, and positive when redirecting their attention to a positive behaviour or activity. 
ğŸŒ· Praise them for this positive behaviour!
Supporting Positive Child Behaviour.tips.message.2.text:
2ï¸âƒ£ KNOW WHAT TO IGNORE

ğŸ’¡ Whining, demanding, showing off, tantrums, and other negative attention-seeking behaviours can be ignored. There are no bad children, only difficult behaviours!
ğŸš© If we respond to negative behaviours, our children learn that this behaviour will get them attention, so they will do it again. They might also learn that if they increase their demand, they will get their way.
â— Some behaviours that should NOT be ignored are: hitting siblings, coming home late, or doing something dangerous. We will learn about how to manage these behaviours in the next module.
Supporting Positive Child Behaviour.tips.message.3.text:
3ï¸âƒ£ IGNORE THE BEHAVIOUR, NOT YOUR CHILD

ğŸŒ± When you ignore your child's behaviour (but not your child!), your child learns that the demanding behaviour will not work.
ğŸ’¡ Ignoring behaviour means looking away and not talking or responding to them until they behave a different way. You should still be aware of what your child is doing.
â° This takes time and patience. Often your child will behave worse to get the attention. Take a pause, stay calm, and keep ignoring the behaviour.
Supporting Positive Child Behaviour.tips.message.4.text:
4ï¸âƒ£ PRAISE THE POSITIVE 

â˜€ï¸ Praise your childâ€™s next positive behaviour.
ğŸˆ Once your child has calmed down after showing demanding behaviour, they will need lots of love and attention on positive behaviour.
ğŸ§¸ You can talk later or the next day about the demanding behaviour. For now, involve your child in a positive activity.
Supporting Positive Child Behaviour.tips.message.5.text:
5ï¸âƒ£ BE CONSISTENT 

â­ Even if your child behaves worse to get attention, it is important to continue ignoring the behaviour. Over time, your child will learn that this demanding behaviour does not work.
ğŸ’š Spend lots of positive time with your child - especially right after a demanding behaviour. Positive one-on-one time is super important!
